title.narrative: Traditional Knowledge, Landscape Management, and Climate Change: A Comprehensive Approach to Manage and Conserve Highland Wetlands in the Peruvian Tropical Andes

description.narrative: The Japu indigenous community territory is situated in the Andean highland wetlands of Peru, within the Vilcabamba– Amboró Conservation Corridor, a mosaic of forests that play an important role in biological connectivity between Manu National Park and the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve. These highland wetlands (or bofedales) store water and prevent soil from eroding downhill when the ecosystems are healthy. The bofedales are home to wild vicuña (Vicugna vicugna), Andean deer (Hippocamelus antisensis), Andean fox (Lycalopex culpaeus) and pumas (Puma concolor). Due to harsh environmental conditions at the altitudes where bofedales are typically found communities subsist on camelid husbandry (alpacas, llamas, and vicuñas). This project will partner with the Japu community to address increasing threats from overgrazing and droughts in this unique ecosystem to conserve endangered and endemic species of flora and fauna. Specific activities include: (1) define rules for the use of bofedales and validate agreements with community members for implementing the management plan; (2) restore degraded bofedales with native species; (3) improve water availability and distribution; (4) develop animal health program to improve camelids’ health and increase wool and meat yields; and (5) monitor implementation of grazing management plan.

description.narrative: U.S. assistance builds the capacity of Peruvian institutions to combat transnational organized crime more effectively, improve citizen security and social inclusion, sustainably manage Peru's diverse and fragile environment, and expand the benefits of Peru's economic progress to more of its citizens. Peru is one of the world's largest cocaine producers, a major money laundering center, a principal source of illegally logged timber and illegally mined gold, and the largest source of counterfeit U.S. currency worldwide. While economic growth has slowed for the past two years due to a slump in international commodity prices and the failure to implement second generation reforms, successive Peruvian governments have pursued judicious, market-based economic policies yielding over a decade of economic growth averaging five percent, which has halved poverty rates, reduced infant mortality, increased lifespans, and expanded access to education. Peru is one of the United States' most steadfast democratic partners in the region, and the continuation of bi-lateral assistance advances U.S. national security and economic interests.
